chunks.text: In this tutorial I'll show you what normal maps are and how you can use them to add a lot of detail to your meshes.

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: So let's say we have a surface made of triangles and we want to add more detail to it.

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: A good way to increase the amount of detail it has would be to add more normals so the light

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: can better interact with the surface. But we can only have normals where we have our vertices.

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: So to add more normals we would have to increase the amount of triangles present which could

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: hit our performance pretty hard. This is where the beauty of normal maps comes in. We can keep

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: the original count of triangles and instead just wrap a normal map onto the surface. Now every pixel

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: on this normal map will represent one normal for the surface. So we just improve the look of the

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: model a lot while barely hitting the performance of our program. Now let's take a better look at a

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: normal map. As you can see they are usually very similar to the diffuse map except they are sort

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: of violet. That is because each pixel of a normal map represents a vector in three dimensions.

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: So in other words the RGB of each pixel stands for the XYZ coordinates. The Z axis aka blue value

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: comes out of the surface and since normals are usually perpendicular to the surface they are on

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: the normal map is dominated by this violet color. So if something is more reddish then the normal

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: is pointing to the right. Well if it is more greenish it is pointing up. One last thing to note

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: is that our RGB is in the range 0,1 but we want our normals in the range minus 1,1 so they can also

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: point in the negative XY and Z axis. So you just need to apply a small transformation when retrieving them.

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: Let's know code it in. You want to start off with a plane that faces the positive Z axis.

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: Now we'll slightly modify our texture class to accept normal maps. The thing about normal maps

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: and basically any sort of texture besides diffuse textures is that we don't want gamma correction on them.

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: So we need to load normal maps as RGB not as RGB. Don't forget to also load in the texture and send

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: it off to the fragment shader. Now all that's left to do is to read the normals of the normal map,

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: transform them to the negative 1,1 range and we're done. You should now have a normal map on your plane.

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: And this is nice, but you'll notice that if I move the plane from its position the normal map

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: will be suddenly wrong. That's because the normal map always points towards the positive Z direction,

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: while in this case our plane is flat on the ground and pointing in the positive Y direction.

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: This discrepancy causes the error we see. We want the normal map and lighting variables to be

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: in the same space. To do that we need a so-called tbn matrix which is made out of the tangent,

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: by tangent and normal of the surface. To get this we can use this formula. If you're interested

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: in its derivation I'll have some links in the description to some articles on it. Now since we need

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: all three vertices of a triangle for the formula you can either calculate the tbn matrix on the cpu

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: or in the geometry shader. I will do it in the geometry shader. So in the default geometry shader

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: that changes nothing we want to sort of by calculating the two edges into delta texture coordinate

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: values from the formula. Then we calculate the division float and finally the tangent and by tangent.

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: Now we want to import the model matrix into the geometry shader so we can multiply the tangent

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: and by tangent. As for the normal we want it to be perpendicular to the triangle but usually not

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: all vertex normals are like that. So instead of getting it from the vertex we'll calculate it as

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: the cross product between the edges we have. Keep in mind the order of the edges matters in the

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: cross product and now we can put all of them together and we have our tbn matrix. We now have two

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: options. We either get the normal map to the same space as the other lighting variables or we get

chunks.text: the other lighting variables to the same space as the normal map. The first option sounds nicer

chunks.text: but it is actually worse since we can only do that in the fragment shader while we can do the second

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: option in the geometry shader. Since the fragment shader runs many more times than the geometry shader

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: it is preferable to take the second option. To do that we first need to inverse the tbn matrix

chunks.text: but inversing matrices is pretty expensive. Thankfully this matrix is a nor-togonal matrix which is

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
chunks.text: the transpose which is much faster. If I sound like I'm talking gibberish to you watch

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4

chunks.title: Normal Maps.mp4
